scenario:
The Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIG) has outperformed the S&P 500 over the past three, five, and 10 years due to its focus on growth stocks with high dividend yields. The fund has a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 25 and a dividend yield of 1.7%, compared to a P/E of 27 and a 1.2% yield for the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF. VIG has over 330 holdings and a 0.06% expense ratio, making it an inexpensive way to achieve diversification.

The fund prioritizes earnings and dividend growth, focusing on companies that have a history of raising their dividends. Top holdings include Apple, Microsoft, Broadcom, JPMorgan Chase, and UnitedHealth Group, with over 83% of the fund invested in five sectors: technology, financials, healthcare, industrials, and consumer staples.

The fund's holdings have a track record of raising their dividends, with companies like Apple and Microsoft having 13 and 15 years of consecutive dividend raises, respectively. The financial sector, which includes JPMorgan and Bank of America, has a relatively inexpensive valuation and includes many excellent value and dividend stocks.

The Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF is a good fit for investors looking for a balanced portfolio of quality businesses with a runway for earnings and dividend growth. It is a good alternative to the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF for those looking to avoid companies that don't pay dividends. The fund's structure weeds out high-flying, unprofitable growth stocks or companies that lack consistent earnings growth.
